awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Fostering Transferable Skills for Future-Ready Extraterrestrial Construction Workforce via an Intelligent-Immersive Training Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
The vision of becoming an interplanetary species requires the construction industry to face an unprecedented challenge: extraterrestrial construction. We envision the future frontier of the construction industry as extraterrestrial construction where the role of workers and their required skills will be significantly different. For the envisioned future extraterrestrial construction industry, our interdisciplinary research team is interested in exploring how Industry 4.0 emerging technologies rooted in digitalization and artificial intelligence can enable a future-ready construction workforce by integrating transferable skills into training environments. In this project, the guiding principles are (1) developing a better understanding of definition, hierarchy, and categorization of transferable skills in the context of future extraterrestrial workforce development, and (2) exploring and advancing training environments enabled by adapting emerging technologies and with a focus on transferable skills to make the existing workers become ready for the future frontier. Our interdisciplinary team will investigate the technological and human dimensions of this vision.

This project will investigate and identify the nature of future extraterrestrial construction and the hierarchy of the skills required by future workers, as well as emerging technologies that can be utilized to integrate transferable skills for developing a future-ready workforce. In addition, we will design, prototype, and evaluate an intelligent-immersive training environment using AI-assisted, simulation-based virtual constructs on training the existing workers in specific transferable skills to make them ready for the future frontier. In particular, the project team will explore and prototype an intelligent-immersive training environment that addresses the needs for training working professionals to foster transferable skills of future extraterrestrial construction workers. The research effort will advance existing knowledge in the following three main areas: (1) the effectiveness of the intelligent-immersive training environment for fostering transferable skills, i.e., computational thinking, fluid reasoning, and agility, (2) the effectiveness of the training environment for improving knowledge acquisition, retention, and performance of future extraterrestrial construction workers and (3) an AI-based approach to learning scaffolding and personalized learning in order to address specific needs of working professionals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Imagine humans building habitats on the Moon or Mars—a reality NASA and other space agencies plan to achieve by 2040. Such extraterrestrial construction, however, is vastly different from construction on Earth due to extreme environmental conditions like radiation, low gravity, and harsh temperatures. To tackle these challenges, human construction workers will collaborate closely with robots, performing tasks remotely or in partnership with automated systems. Preparing this new workforce requires innovative training approaches. This project developed a groundbreaking training solution using Virtual Reality (VR) to teach essential problem-solving skills in human-robot collaboration - computational thinking (CT). CT involves breaking complex tasks into simpler components, recognizing patterns, and systematically developing solutions—skills vital for successful human-robot teamwork.

A virtual interdisciplinary workshop brought together experts from leading universities, NASA, and industry partners to outline the specific requirements for future extraterrestrial construction and identify the skills that future workers must possess. Through this collaboration, the team identified crucial competencies like situational awareness, remote equipment operation, adaptability to unexpected situations, trust in technology, and the ability to work effectively alongside robots.

An innovative VR training environment was developed to foster these competencies, enabling students to interactively and safely learn critical problem-solving techniques in virtual scenarios simulating Earth-based and space-based construction environments. Students learned computational thinking skills—breaking down complex problems (decomposition), identifying patterns (pattern recognition), simplifying information (abstraction), and systematically designing solutions (algorithms)—all while engaging in realistic, hands-on robotic construction tasks. Initial testing with undergraduate students in Construction Management at Louisiana State University showed that participants who trained in the VR environment significantly improved their computational thinking and problem-solving abilities, becoming faster, more accurate, and more confident in handling robotic equipment compared to their peers who did not receive CT-focused training. Participants also highlighted that the VR environment allowed them to strategically approach problems, iteratively refine their techniques based on real-time feedback, and feel more prepared to face unexpected scenarios.

This pilot study demonstrates the significant potential of immersive, virtual reality-based training environments in preparing the future workforce for highly technical roles, both on Earth and beyond. Not only does this approach provide safer, more engaging, and more realistic training experiences, but it also equips learners with flexible problem-solving skills vital for adapting to technological advancements in any industry.

Moving forward, expanding this training to diverse industries will validate and enhance its impact. Future advancements will integrate AI for personalized learning, improving skill retention. This research highlights the power of computational thinking and VR in developing a tech-savvy construction workforce ready for 21st-century challenges and space exploration.
